newsitem.title: CANADA: Inco Ltd shares to be released to Friedland.
newsitem.headline: Inco Ltd shares to be released to Friedland.

text.p: The United States Department of Justice said on Thursday it will not seek a court order to delay the release of shares in Inco Ltd that are owned by financier Robert Friedland, Vancouver-based Ivanhoe Capital Corp said.
The shares were worth US$152 million when they were seized in August after court hearings in the U.S. and Canada.
Ontario Court General Division Justice Robert Sharpe on Tuesday condemned the U.S. for what he called a pervasive failure to disclose vital facts to the courts, the company said in a statement.

Evidence showed that the U.S. did not have a strong case in alleging Friedland was liable for costs incurred by the Environmental Protection Agency in remedying environmental problems at the Summitville gold mine site in Colorado, Ivanhoe's statement said.
Friedland controlled the former gold mine through Galactic Resources Ltd, a company he founded in the 1980s.
He gained the Inco stocks as part of Inco's takeover last August of Diamond Fields Resources, a company run by Friedland.
The EPA wanted Friedland's assets frozen since it said it had a strong case against him in Colorado.
Judge Sharpe ordered that the shares be returned to Friedland.

Friedland agreed to retain the shares in Ontario until 1630 EST on Friday to give the U.S. time to consider whether it would ask the Appeal Court to impose a stay, pending an appeal, the statement said.
U.S. counsel Malcolm Ruby told Friedland's lawyer on Thursday the United States "will not be seeking a stay" of Judge Sharpe's order, the statement said.
